filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of the electronic editions of The Marriage of Heaven and Hell Copies K, L, and M. The Archive is also publishing the collection list for the Victoria University Library in Toronto and Alexander Gourlay's revised Glossary of Terms, Names, and Concepts in Blake.
Blake etched twenty-seven plates for Marriage in relief in 1790. Copy K is an early printing of Plates 21-24, and Copies L and M are early printings of Plates 25-27, "A Song of Liberty." Copy K is in the Fitzwilliam Museum, Copy L is in the Essick Collection, and Copy M, formerly in the Bentley Collection, is in the Victoria University Library. Only nine complete copies of the Marriage are known to exist; Copies K, L, and M, apparently printed as autonomous pamphlets, join six complete copies previously published in the Archive (and now republished with corrected transcriptions).
The four plates of Copy K were printed in black ink on both sides of a single sheet of wove paper, folded down the middle after printing to form two leaves. Plate 21 is in its first state and the vignette on Plate 24 is missing, probably masked during printing but possibly not yet executed. In Copies L and M, Plate 25 is in its first state, and thus these copies were also printed very early in the production process; in Copy M, the eight lines of the "Chorus" on Plate 27 were masked during printing. The plates were printed on single sheets folded down the middle to form pamphlets of two leaves. Copy L was printed in brownish-black on laid paper and Copy M was printed in grayish-black on wove paper.
Like all the illuminated books in the Archive, the text and images of Marriage Copies K, L, and M are fully searchable and are supported by our Inote and ImageSizer applications. With the Archive's Compare feature, users can easily juxtapose multiple impressions of any plate across the different copies of this or any of the other illuminated books. New protocols for transcription, which produce improved accuracy and fuller documentation in editors' notes, have been applied to all copies of Marriage in the Archive.
With the publication of Marriage Copies K, L, and M, the Archive now contains fully searchable and scalable electronic editions of sixty-five copies of Blake's nineteen illuminated books in the context of full bibliographic information about each work, careful diplomatic transcriptions of all texts, detailed descriptions of all images, and extensive bibliographies. In addition to illuminated books, the Archive contains many important manuscripts and series of engravings, sketches, and water color drawings, including Blake's illustrations to Thomas Gray's Poems, water color and engraved illustrations to Dante's Divine Comedy, the large color printed drawings of 1795 and c. 1805, the Linnell and Butts sets of the Book of Job water colors and the sketchbook containing drawings for the engraved illustrations to the Book of Job, the water color illustrations to Robert Blair's The Grave, and the water color illustrations to John Milton's Paradise Regained, L'Allegro, and Il Penseroso, as well as the Butts and Thomas sets of illustrations to Milton's Comus, Nativity ode, and Paradise Lost.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A curly-haired and youthful nude male with his head up to the right sits on a hilltop or mound. His right hand (and presumably his left, behind his back) rests on the ground to support the weight of his upper body. His feet—the right foot more prominent and forward—are drawn up toward his groin and his legs are spread wide apart, genitals exposed but not clearly printed in this copy. His left knee rests on a human skull.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The smaller figures, interspersed among various vegetative designs, all appear immediately above the first line of text: at the far left, a gowned and winged female reaches her arms out to a small child who leans slightly toward her. The female rests against a grain tassel. Following a combination of stylized leaves and a three-looped vine, a child and adult face each other, the former lying with head raised, the latter kneeling with hands on ground or holding the child's hand. To their right, the final figure sits reading on a vegetable surface. A leaf-like extension arches above the figure. Further down, an elaborate sequence of sinuous, looped vines and squiggles, as well as a branch with spiky leaves, follows "reasoning" in line 4 and stretches to the right margin. Another such sequence occurs right of line 7, where wavy lines and other vegetative motifs follow the two words of text, "publish'd books." A vine with leaves(?) immediately precedes the catchword "one."

component.illusobjdesc: Directly above "I have" in line 1, a gowned female reaches her arms out to a small child who leans slightly toward her. The child faces right, standing on a leaf.

To the right of the woman, the grain or leaf stem grows into two scanty leaves or branches. Continuing the mixed vegetative motif, a triple-looped, serpentine vine—suggestive of a spiral—extends from the leaves toward the next pair of figures.

Above "that Angels" in line 1, a child and an adult face each other. The child lies on a vegetative slope. It faces right with head raised. The child has at least one arm extended toward the adult and may be holding the adult's hand.

Above "that Angels" in line 1, a child and an adult face each other. The adult faces left and down, perhaps looking at the child. The figure appears to be either kneeling with hands on ground or holding the child's hand.
Beneath the child and female and above "that Angels" in line 1, a wavy, serpentine line represents a vegetative surface, perhaps a continuation of the vine motif on the left.

On the far right of the plate and above the first line of text, the final figure in the series sits reading on a vegetative surface, perhaps a leaf. The figure faces right, a book propped on its knees. A leaf arches over the figure.
On the far right of the plate and above the first line of text, a figure sits reading on a leaf or frond; a leaf-like canopy arches over the figure.

An elaborate sequence of snake-like, looped vines and serpentine motifs follow "reasoning" in line 4. The designs, which conclude with a branch bearing spiky leaves, stretch to the right margin of the plate. A similar sequence occurs right of line 7, where wavy lines, one prominent leaf, and/or other vegetative motifs predominate over the two words of text, "publish'd books."
A vine-like loop, which looks like a bird with neck and head twisted to the right, precedes line 8. A leaf precedes line 5 and a vine with leaves(?) precedes the catchword "one."

illustration.illusobjdesc: At the end of line 1, a scrolled shape with wavy lines intersecting its midsection has been seen as a sea creature entangled in the remnants of a net; the scene as a whole is said to illustrate the text that continues from the previous plate, which describes Swedenborg's self-deceptions: he imagines "himself the single / one on earth that ever broke a net." In this copy, the shape seems vegetative or worm-like. Beyond this shape, a hunched figure (probably holding a book or tablet) sits on a vine. Following "falshoods" in line 4, a figure clad in a billowing garment hovers amidst some vegetation. Below, two elaborate spirals radiate from a common center right of line 8. To the right of "further" in line 11 are several large leaves. Next to "number" in line 16, three birds soar on extended wings. To the left of the long-tailed bird and below the small, nondescript bird are two swollen vegetable forms. A loop extending from the "h" of "he" at the end of line 17 coincides with the wing of the largest bird. Four figures bound the plate's inscription, "A Memorable Fancy" (line 20), on three sides. The first figure reclines beneath some leaves and branches to the left of the text. The vegetation transforms into loops and squiggles clinging to the margin of the plate. Above the inscription, a hovering figure, arm(s) extended, seems to reach for a serpent. The four-looped vine growing from the "F" of "Fancy" and the squiggly "y" of the same word continue the serpentine motif. To the right of the text, the third figure of the vignette stands facing right with arms raised at 135 degrees. His head is bent back, and his posture suggests he has just been impaled by the invisible arrow released from the bow of the fourth figure, who leaps through the air brandishing the weapon. Behind him, a snake or vine coils around a tall tuft of grass. Further down, a flower with leaves and/or thorns adorns the space following "words" in line 23. Right of the flower, a flying bird or insect appears to carry a vine through the air, recalling similar motifs on Plates 5, 15, and 19, although this may only be more vegetation in this copy. A vegetable form follows, with another large leaf or vine extending horizontally below the last line of text, lower left. Ornamenting the left margin are various other small-scale vegetative designs attached to letters.

At the end of line 1 near the right margin, a small figure sits with hunched shoulders on a vine. The figure faces left. It seems to hold a book or tablet. Thus, the figure may be reading or writing.
Various swirls and lines crossing the blue wash at the end of line 1 suggest vines.

Following "falshoods" in line 4 is a hovering figure swathed in billowing garments. The swirls and folds of the garment appear vegetative in nature. The figure appears to be facing left and down, with one arm extended and perhaps pointing to the left.

Following "falshoods" in line 4 is a figure swathed in billowing garments. The swirls and folds of the garment appear vegetative in nature, and the figure is flanked by a small leaf-bearing branch on the left and flat, stylized leaves or ribbons on the right.

Following "notions" in line 8, two long, loopy vines—cf. a similar interlinear motif on Plate 15—radiate from a common center. The first four loops in the spiral on the right reverse the direction of those on the left.
Three leaves, the first of which is particularly large and broad, appear to the right of "further" in line 11.
Following "number" in line 16, three birds soar on extended wings. The bird on the far left has a particularly long, forked tail.

To the left of the long-tailed bird and below the smaller, nondescript bird at the end of line 16 are two swollen vegetable forms. A vine-like loop extending from the "h" of "he" at the end of line 17 coincides with the wing of the largest bird.

Four figures bound the plate's inscription, "A Memorable Fancy," on three sides in line 20. The first figure reclines beneath some leaves and branches to the left of the text. Like Ezekiel in Plate 13, this figure lies on its side, but—unlike the prophet—it faces the viewer with head resting on hand.

The first of four figures that ornament the space around the plate's inscription reclines beneath some leaves and branches to the left of the text. The vegetative canopy arches over the figure. The slope on which it lies is vine-like, becoming snaky—i.e., loopy and serpentine—as it clings to and climbs the left margin.

Above the inscription, "A Memorable Fancy," in line 20, the second figure hovers, facing right. Its legs are apart; one of them is extended backward and bent slightly at the knee. The figure's body is horizontal. Arm(s) outstretched, it seems to reach for the squiggly snake in front of it.
The hovering figure above the plate's inscription, "A Memorable Fancy," in line 20 seems to reach for the squiggly serpent in front of it. The serpent faces right; its mouth is open.

To the right of the plate's inscription, "A Memorable Fancy," a nude male stands facing right with arms raised at 135 degrees. His hands are turned with palms facing up. The figure's head is bent back, and his legs are together; leaning backward, he appears to have just been impaled by the invisible arrow released from the bow of the fourth figure.

Facing the third figure who stands leaning slightly backward to the right of the plate's inscription, a nude figure leaps through the air brandishing a bow in its right arm. The left arm is drawn back. One leg is bent at the knee and extended backward.

The four-looped, spiraling vine growing from the "F" of "Fancy" in line 20 and the squiggly "y" of the same word continue the serpentine motif of the plate and the vignette. Behind the nude figure who leaps through the air brandishing a bow, a snake(?) or vine coils around a tall tuft of grass near the right margin of the plate.
Near the right margin of the plate and following the inscription, "A Memorable Fancy," in line 20, the form coiled around a tall tuft of grass might be a snake.
A flower with leaves and/or thorns adorns the space following "words" in line 23.

Next to the flower at the end of line 23, a bird or an insect flies on extended wings with vegetation attached to it. The creature appears to be facing up. The motif recalls similar hybrids on Plates 5, 15, and 19.

Next to the flower at the end of line 23, a bird or an insect flies on extended wings with vegetation attached to it. Two more vegetable forms follow, the first of which is in this copy attached to the vegetation held by the hybrid creature.
A large vine extends horizontally beneath the last line of text.

Ornamenting the left margin of the plate are various small-scale vegetative motifs, most of which are attached to letters, e.g., the leafy flourish off the "N" of "Now" in line 2 and the serpentine vines growing next to the "A" of "And" in line 5 and from the "H" of "Have" in line 12. Vines or small leaves appear left of the first letters of the first words in lines 9 and 17.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Sundry figure and animal motifs appear below the text: in the lower left corner of the plate, a snake with a gaping mouth(?) faces left. Next to it is what appears to be an upside-down human figure, head on the right and upper left leg on the left. Continuing the sequence, a hovering figure facing down is followed by another snake. A final figure also lies on its side, but the viewer sees it from behind. Various vegetative motifs adorn the left and especially the right margin, e.g., the serpentine vine bearing a leaf and/or bud following "replied" in line 5.

component.illusobjdesc: In the bottom left corner of the plate, a snake with an enormous, gaping mouth(?) faces left.

In other copies, the second motif from the left at the bottom of the plate clearly depicts a figure on hands and knees, upside-down. In Copy K, however, the form appears to be an upside-down falling figure, with arms raised vertically, head on the right facing up, and upper leg on the left.

At the bottom of the plate, the third design from the left depicts a figure facing down, its body slightly curved and perhaps falling. One or both arms are raised vertically (in relation to the figure's head); the figure appears to rest its head in the crook of its arm. Its legs are together.
At the bottom of the plate, a snake(?), or possibly just a thick vine, is flanked by two human figures.

Following the snake at the bottom of the plate, the last figure of the series lies on its side. The figure is seen from behind. One leg is extended; the other is drawn up and bent at the knee. The nude figure rests its head on one arm, which is bent at the elbow.

Various vegetative motifs adorn the left and especially the right margin, e.g., the snaky vine bearing a leaf or bud following "replied" in line 5; the somewhat anthropomorphic, vine-like squiggles following "he" in line 13; and the leaf-bearing, serpentine shape next to "virtue" in line 23.
Following "virtue" in line 23, a snake-like vine bearing a single leaf resembles a small, winged serpent facing left.

objnote.p: This impression lacks the design below the text and the proverb beneath the design. These were probably masked during printing, but might not have been executed on the copperplate. All other known impressions include the design and proverb.

illustration.illusobjdesc: At the top of the plate, following "rules" in line 1, a hunched-over figure sits with its head resting on its knees at one end of a serpentine vegetative motif. Completing the vignette is another figure striding along the wavy ascender of "the" in line 2. The figure faces right, arm(s) raised horizontally and a scarf floating behind it. Next to "Elijah" at the end of line 4, a gowned figure hovers, facing left. A winged figure seen from behind hovers in the left margin between lines 4 and 5; leaf-like forms appear to the right. A serried scene of six sundry figures—flanked by books on the right and more books, or possibly vegetation, on the left—also appears between the text of lines 4 and 5. Each of the figures sits or kneels; the left-most figure appears to be reading. A small horse leaps right above "world" in line 8. Following "well" at the end of the same line, a figure runs rightward, reaching for a small child. The top half of the plate is dense with interlinear loops, vines, banners, and leaves, e.g., the vines and/or roots on either side of the figures populating the space between lines 4 and 5; the looped vines growing from the descender of "my" and the ascender of "friend," both in line 6; the elaborate curlicues following the text of line 10; and the small branch with spiky leaves extending from the "l" of "also" in line 9. Wing-like vegetable objects and/or soaring birds grace the plate—above "have" and "whether" in lines 8 and 10 respectively, for example.
